name: Full adder
description:
A full adder is a digital circuit that adds two binary numbers along with a carry input and produces a sum output and a carry output. The circuit consists of two half adders and an additional OR gate that combines the carry output of the two half adders.

The first half adder takes two binary inputs A and B and produces a sum output S and a carry output C1. The second half adder takes the sum output S and a carry input C2, which is the carry output from the previous half adder, and produces a final sum output and carry output.

The overall operation of the full adder is as follows: the input bits A and B are added along with the carry input C, and the sum output S and carry output C_out are produced. The sum output S is the binary sum of the three inputs, while the carry output C_out is the carry that is propagated to the next stage of the adder circuit.

The full adder is a fundamental building block of arithmetic circuits, and is used extensively in the design of microprocessors, digital signal processors, and other digital circuits.
